Subject files: Skiing (broadcasting)

Caption: To Mr. Lowell Thomas, Compliments and Best Wishes, C. C. Stafford; Note: Lowell Thomas recently scaled Mount Mansfield, the highest peak in the Green Mountains, on skis, with a temperature at forty below. That night he gave a description of his experience on his regular Sunoco News Broadcast, from the Green Mountain Inn at Stowe, Vermont. Reading from left to right, Joe Fountain, official of the New Haven, Central Vermont and Canadian National Railroads; Lowell Thomas, broadcasting; Bob Isham, Vermont ski authority; and Jacques Charmoz, explorer, famous skier and chief instructor to the Chilean Army; Caption: To Mr. Lowell Thomas; Compliments and Best Wishes [signed] C.C. Stafford

Note: Lowell Thomas recently scaled Mount Mansfield, the highest peak in the Green Mountains, on skis, with a temperature at forty below. That night he gave a description of his experience on his regular Sunoco News Broadcast, from the Green Mountain Inn at Stowe, Vermont. Reading from left to right, Joe Fountain, official of the New Haven, Central Vermont and Canadian National Railroads; Lowell Thomas, broadcasting; Bob Isham, Vermont ski authority; and Jacques Charmoz, explorer, famous skier and chief instructor to the Chilean Army; Caption: To Mr. Lowell Thomas; Compliments and Best Wishes [signed] C.C. Stafford

This is a clearer print than the one I sent you; Left to right, front row: L.T. Jr., Lady who was McClelland Barclay's No. 1 model at that time. Seated in front, with hands crossed - - Harry Wheeler, today owner of the Greyrocks Inn, and at that time he was rather famous for his dog team racing - - the Val d'Or. Sitting right behind him is Mary Bird Young. Middle row: McClelland Barclay, famous artist, ? , L.T. , Mary Ryan in white, Hans Faulkner, Chris Young. Back row: - With glasses (standing), white shirt and black tie, Oscar Landry, CPR station agent at St. Jovite. Seated next to him, eyes half closed, is Tom Wheeler, present owner of Lac Ouimette Inn and the Wheeler Airlines which serves Arctic Canada, the Dew Line and so on. Extreme right, smiling, Joe Ryan; Verso: credit Lowell Thomas; "Ski Down the Years," chapt. TEN - page 193 (top)

Subject files: Skiing (ski trophy in honor of Vic Constant)

[PDF] Note: I've been going through some thousands of pictures, selecting illustrations for the second volume of my autobiography. I gave this trophy in honor of Captain Vic Constant, coach of the West Point ski team back in the late thirties or early forties. Vic was killed when he was making a preliminary run down the Taft Trail in New Hampshire. It was the day before he was to have raced in the Nationals. He was a friend of mine, and much admired by all of us who were active in skiing at the time; Sincerely, Lowell Thomas; To Athletic Director of West Point, West Point, Madeline Salvani c.o Athletic Director U.S. Military Academy West Point, New York; 914-938-3303 (Lt. Gen. Sidney Berry) Captain McPhail - 938-4011, Maj. Campbell, Captain Hansen

Canadian Pacific Railway Photo; Leading Winter Sports Personalities: Lowell Thomas, second from right, noted radio commentator and familiar figure on Eastern Canadian ski slopes for many years, is welcomed to the Lac Beauport booth at the recent International Winter Sports Show in New York by Fritz Loosli, director of the Chateau Frontenac Ski Hawk School, and Fritz and Marili Tschannen, in costume. Tschannen, holder of the world's ski-jumping record for three years and winner of 362 first prizes in the national and international ski competitions, will instruct in the Loosli school at Lac Beauport this Winter; Verso: Tschaennens, Loosli and Thomas

Subject files: Softball (Nine Old Men versus the Statesmen in Washington, D.C.)

Cooling off the Vice-President; Washington, D.C. Senator James M. Mead of New York is pictured fanning Vice-President Wallace after the V-P crossed the plate with a run in the second inning of their annual game here in Washington. Lowell Thomas captained the "Nine Old Men" team, while Rep. Ham Fish of New York, led the "Statesman" team. The game played for charity, lasted eight innings and was won by the "Statesmen" by a score of 15-14; M-6-3-41..1240PM

Subject files: Softball (Gene Tunney)

(Tunney Batting); Boxer Tunney a Slugger? New Canaan, Conn.Though his form can be described by a word that begins with an "L" and ends with a "Y" (not lovely), retired heavyweight king -- now columnist, Gene Tunney, is shown belting out a clean hit as his Fourth Estate "Connecticut Nutmegs" met commentator Lowell Thomas's "Nine Old Men" in a charity soft ball game yesterday. That's Thomas behind the bat. Note Gene's left foot "in the bucket." It would bring a nervous breakdown for any baseball manager. The Tunney bunch won 10-9

Note: (Tunney Batting); Boxer Tunney a Slugger? INSTRUCTIONS TO THE UMPIRE; Poundridge, N.Y. --- Not in the least disturbed by the declaration of umpire Anna May Wong that she "knew less than nothing" about baseball, Lowell, Thomas undertakes to explain the difference between a strike and a ball to the actress before the start of the game between his "Nine Old Men" and George T. Bye's "Prehistoric Sluggers" in Flaucher's Meadows August 15 for the benefit of the local volunteer fire department. Apparently he did a good job, for the "Nine Old Men" won by a score of 15 to 12. Members of both teams were well-known persons from literary and entertainment circles. 0-8/16/37 8
